Chlorine gas then flows from the evaporators through the temperature-actuated control valve to the chlorinators.  The chlorinators are used to control the feed rate of the chlorine gas.  The chlorinators are equipped with a gas meter and v-notched orifice for controlling the feed rate.  Injection of the chlorine into the process water produces the concentrated chlorine solution that flows through rubber-lined ductile Iron piping to the various injection points in the treatment process.

The Alexander Orr WTP chlorine systems are provided with a number of safety features to protect the employees and the surrounding community.  Safety features include, but are not limited to emergency shut-off valves, chlorine leak detectors, audio and visual alarm system, isolation valves, high and low temperature alarms, high and low pressure alarms, pressure regulators, expansion tanks, bursting disks, and pressure relief valves.  Chlorine C Kits and personal protective equipment, including self-contained breathing apparatus are available in the event of a chlorine release.  These major safety features are located in the chlorine car enclosure and the chlorinator rooms.

Emergency shut-off valves are located immediately after the rail car valve. Downstream of the manifold system there is also a pneumatically actuated emergency shut-off valve.  Pulling one of the emergency shut-off switches (kill switches) activates the emergency shut-off valves.  The emergency shut-off switches are located at the chlorine car enclosure and at the chlorinator rooms.

The emergency response plan has been coordinated with local response agencies (Fire Department, Miami-Dade Office of Emergency Management).  The main elements of the emergency response plan are: (1) chlorine release response flow chart, responsibilities of various personnel at the facility, duties of on-scene incident commander, site response team, and site safety representative, (2) details of emergency recognition and prevention at the facility, (3) procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations, and (4) details of the training program for all employees involved with the chlorination processes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
Numerous changes to improve safety were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1997 for chlorination and system equipment and procedures, when Process Safety Management (PSM) Plans were prepared.  All of these recommended actions were evaluated for implementation as required. MDWASD is currently in the process of evaluating and implementing recommendations from the June 9-10, 2014 PHA.  

MDWASD is committed to providing a safe and healthful work environment to its employees, while protecting the public, on-site and off-site property, and the environment from releases of chlorine.

Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  

Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  There are two methods of chlorination, breakpoint chlorination and chloramination.  The breakpoint chlorination process consists of adding enough chlorine to the water to satisfy the chlorine demand so that free available chlorine residual can be measured.  Chloramination is the process of adding chlorine and ammonia to water, which produces a mono-chloramine residual.  The Miami-Dade Water and Sewer Department (MDWASD) Alexander Orr Water Treatment Plant (WTP) uses chlorine and aqueous ammonia for disinfecting and lowering the trihalomethane levels in finished drinking water, to protect public health and to comply with state and federal water quality standards.  

Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  The Alexander Orr WTP takes safety obligations in storing and using all chemicals seriously, as it takes care in providing safe drinking water.

The Alexander Orr WTP chlorine handling processes is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule.  This rule requires submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and an update to the RMP every five (5) years.  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the chlorine process, including a description of the possible consequences if the procedures are not followed, and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of a chlorine release.

Training
Alexander Orr WTP employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine processes are trained in the chlorine process and the applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Alexander Orr WTP ensures that each employee newly assigned to the chlorine process, is trained and tested to be competent in the process safety management, standard operating procedures, consequences of deviation from the SOPs, and chlorine process safety features.   Each employee involved in operating the chlorine system, has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities, including emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.

Management Personnel are trained on Process Safety Management and compliance with Federal and State Regulations pertaining to Risk Management Planning and Process Safety Management.  All on-site facility personnel that are not involved directly with the chlorine system are also trained in the MDWASD Emergency Action Plan, and the hazards of chlorine.

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. 

MDWASD retains records of initial and refresher training, and provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The MDWASD accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven chlorine process technology and safety systems, incorporates staff training, provides detailed information on the hazards of chlorine and process safety management, implements operation and maintenance standard operating procedures, trains and plans for emergency response and emergency actions, includes contractor safety, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  

General Facility and Regulated Substance information
The MDWASD Alexander Orr WTP is located at 6800 SW 87 Avenue, Miami, Florida. The plant is bounded by SW 64th Street, to the north, SW 87 Avenue to the east and by SW 72nd Street (Sunset Dr.) to the south. Alexander Orr WTP covers 68 acres.  The facility stores chlorine which is a regulated toxic substance under RMP rule.

The chlorine system at the Alexander Orr WTP provides chlorine to the softened water to maintain required disinfection levels for drinking water.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Alexander Orr WTP at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantity in the RMP rule. It also exceeds the listed threshold quantity in Process Safety Management Standard.

Chlorine is delivered in  rail cars to a chlorine car enclosure. The rail cars contain liquid chlorine under pressure which is fed to two chlorine facilities designated as Chemical Plant 1 and Chemical Plant 2. The pressure from the stored chlorine in the rail car forces liquid chlorine through the tubing and into the chlorine feed line. Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program
Alexander Orr WTP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting up a new covered process or after a shutdown event, or prior to starting up modifications to the chlorination processes that require a MOC procedure implementation.

Hot Work Permits and Management Change
The Alexander Orr WTP requires that employees and contractors employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the covered process.  The Alexander Orr WTP uses a permitting program to ensure that hot work is conducted safely on, or near a process involving chlorine.   

Internal Compliance Audits
Internal Compliance Audits will be conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The MDWASD will assemble an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the chlorine process.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations evaluated, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

Incident Investigation
The Alexander Orr WTP investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in injury to personnel, injury to the public, damage to the environment, or property damage so that similar accidents can be prevente

d.  An investigation team will be assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are evaluated, and appropriate recommendations are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and used as needed to revise operating and maintenance procedures.

Five-Year Accident History Summary
No reportable releases/accidents have occurred at the Alexander Orr plant during the last 5 years.

Emergency Response Program Summary
The MDWASD emergency response policy involves the preparation and maintenance of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility, and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program Requirements.  Alexander Orr WTP has an Emergency Response Plan and Emergency Action Plan, that staff are trained on and MDWASD coordinates emergency planning with offsite response officials. Training is on-going.

All Alexander Orr WTP employees are trained as first responders.   Additionally, all employees have been trained in the hazards of chlorine, and the MDWASD Emergency Action Plan.  Employees working with the chlorine process are HAZWOPER technician level trained, and receive Process Safety Management training, including training on SOPs, chlorine process safety features, and preventative maintenance procedures.  Management has been trained in Process Safety Management and the regulatory requirements of the Risk Management Planning and Process Safety Management rules.  

Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the Miami-Dade County Hazardous Material Team may be solicited to aid in handling chorine. The leak detection and alarm system in the chlorine car enclosure is activated when chlorine gas is sensed.  The leak detection system is set to activate the alarms when a chlorine concentration of 0.5 ppm or higher is detected.  When the leak detection system detects a leak, both audio and visual alarms are activated.  When the chlorine alarms are engaged, personnel are restricted from entering the chlorine area without the appropriate personnel protective equipment.  A chlorine leak detection and alarm system like the one in the chlorine car enclosure is located inside the chlorinator rooms.  

A perimeter fence and locked security gates surround the Alexander Orr WTP. Security cameras are located throughout the plant and are monitored both on-site and off-site. Security guards are posted at the entrances to the plant and unauthorized access is not allowed. There is also a roving security patrol of the perimeter fence. Employees are onsite 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

The Alexander Orr WTP is also provided with a backup emergency power generator that supplies power to the entire facility.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Alexander Orr WTP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
	* Detailed management system.	
	* Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
	* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
	* Performance of process hazard analysis (PHA) of covered processes, with operation and maintenance staff participation and review, and trained PHA facilitator.
	* Use of the-state-of-the art process and safety equipment and do

cumentation of equipment safety information.
	* Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operations and maintenance personnel, and safety staff.
	* Training of the all facility personnel, including management, operators and maintenance staff, security and all workers at the plant site.
	* Implementation of an incident investigation program.
	* Chemical-specific prevention steps including the  availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine,  presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and remotely controlled shutoff devices on the chlorine storage tanks.
	* Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine. This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets, along with process and chemical safety information.
	* Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provide in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility. 


Process Hazard Analysis
In 1997, a detailed Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) was conducted of the chlorine system process, including safety features, procedures, and maintenance.  The PHA was updated again in 2001, 2004 and 2009 and  recommended actions were developed to further improve safety.  An additional PHA was conducted in 2014 and recommendations are in the process of being evaluated and/or implemented.
